_prev_prog_3.Description: Oleum (Caprolactam II) - Caprolactam I and II units contain Oleum.  Much of the information is consistant for both units.  However, separate elements are submitted to reflect differences in process controls, dates of review, and other prevention program information.

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Recirculation line, valves locked open, redundant water sources, redundant meters, and mechanical integrity program
_prev_prog_3.Description: Oleum (Caprolactam I) - Caprolactam I and II units contain Oleum.  Much of the information is consistant for both units.  However, separate elements are submitted to reflect differences in process controls, dates of review, and other prevention program information.

Propylene Distribution - (Acrylic Monomers)  Acrylic Monomers shares a  propylene distribution system with the Oxo Alcohols unit.  Although the release scenarios are common to both units, separate elements are submitted to reflect differences in dates of review, PHA methodology, and other prevention element data.

Propylene Distribution - (Oxo Alcohols)  Oxo Alcohols and Acrylic Monomers share a propylene distribution system.  Although the release scenarios are common to both units, separate elements are submitted to reflect differences in dates of review, PHA methodology, and other prevention element data.
Polyalcohols - (Trimethylamine and Formaldehyde)  The Neol process contains both formaldehyde and trimethylamine.

Ammonia Distribution - Syngas. Syngas shares a common ammonia distribution system with other onsite units. The release scenario is for the common header. However, separate data elements are presented to reflect differences in prevention element data for each unit.

Ammonia Distribution - (Hydroxylamine)  Hydroxylamine shares a common ammonia distribution system with other on-site units.  The release scenario is for the common header; however, separate data elements are presented to reflect differences in prevention element data for each unit.

Ammonia Distibution - (Caprolactam II)  Caprolactam II shares a common ammonia distribution system with other on-site units.  The release scenario is for the common header; however, separate data elements are presented to reflect differences in prevention element data for each unit.

Ammonia Distibution - (Cyclohexanone 2)  Cyclohexanone 2 shares a common ammonia distribution system with other on-site units.  The release scenario is for the common header; however, separate data elements are presented to reflect differences in prevention element data for each unit.

Ammonia Distibution - (Cyclohexanone 1)  Cyclohexanone 1 shares a common ammonia distribution system with other on-site units.  The release scenario is for the common header; however, separate data elements are presented to reflect differences in prevention element data for each unit.

Ammonia Distibution - (Caprolactam I)  Caprolactam I shares a common ammonia distribution system with other on-site units.  The release scenario is for the common header; however, separate data elements are presented to reflect differences in prevention element data for each unit.

Ammonia Distribution - Polyalcohols  Polyalcohols shares a common ammonia distribution system with other onsite units. The release scenario is for the common header. However, separate data elements are presented to reflect differences in prevention element data for each unit.

Ammonia Railcars - This occurs approximately 2 weeks every 5 years when ammonia pipeline is taken out of service for planned inspection, modification, and/or minor repairs. Railcars of ammonia are brought on site, stored, and off-loaded into D-100 tanks for consumption.

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Liquid ammonia piping from D-5320 to E-5302, through E-5320A/B/C and back to E-5302 or to the suction of P-5320A/B
_prev_prog_3.Description: Ammonia Plant - newly constructed plant to begin operations later this year (2018)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Commitment to the Community

BASF Corporation has a long tradition of operating its facilities in the safest possible manner. BASF also believes in being a responsible corporate citizen and maintaining open, constructive dialogue with our neighbors. These principles are an integral part of our corporate vision statement and values. We believe that sharing this information with our neighbors makes good sense. By doing so, we believe the community will better understand how safe and ecologically sound BASF operations are.



Policies

BASF Corporation has the following Corporate Guidelines related to environmental, health and safety:

+ We produce products that are safe to manufacture, use and dispose of.

+ We assist our customers to use our products safely and in an environmentally sound manner. We provide them with information on correct handling of our products.

+ We minimize the impact on mankind and the environment during production, storage, transportation, marketing and use of our products.

+ Economic considerations do not take priority over environmental protection, health and safety.

+ An important contribution to "Sustainable Development" is our involvement in the "Responsible Care initiative worldwide. This applies to our products and services in all our businesses and affiliates.

+ We are committed to making continuous improvements in safety, health and environmental protection.  We do this acting on our own initiative and in consultation with recognized regulatory authorities. We take any action judged to be necessary, whether or not dictated by statutory obligation or official regulations.

+ We encourage safety, environmental and health awareness among employees.

+ We regard it as an important corporate duty to advance science and technology in order to improve safety and environmental protection.

+ We carefully weigh the potential benefits and risks of new discoveries and technologies in dialogue with scientists and society before deciding on ho

w to proceed.

+ We pursue an open dialogue with all relevant opinion leaders in society. Our goals are to promote and strengthen mutual understanding and deepen trust in what we do.



The BASF Corporation Freeport Site implements these policies through site-specific programs and procedures. The Freeport Site Risk Management Plan information was presented to the community in November 1997.



Facility Description

The BASF Corporation Freeport Site uses seven  RMP regulated chemicals.  The table below provides a summary of the units which use them and some final products which they can be found.

RMP Chemical...............Operating Unit(s)..............End Uses

Oleum.............................Caprolactam I & II.............Nylon fibers and plastics

Ammonia(anhydrous).....Caprolactam I & II 

................................Cyclohexanone I & II

................................Hydroxylamine

................................Neol

................................Acrylic Monomers

................................Oxo Alcohols

................................Ammonia Production ............Fertilizers, nylon fibers, plastics, water craft, appliance and automotive coatings plastic coatings and paints

Hydrogen........................Ammonia Production ............Fertilizers, nylon fibers, plastics, water craft, appliance and automotive coating plastic coating and paints

Formaldehyde.................Neol...........................Water craft, appliance and automotive coatings

Propylene.......................Oxo Alcohols

........................................Acrylic Acid 2&3...............Plastic coatings and paints, Super-absorbent Polymers

Trimethylamine...............Neol...........................Water craft, appliance and automotive coatings

Acrylonitrile.....................Dispersions....................Paper coatings and non-woven binder agents



Title V Operating Permits:

RMP covered processes are operated under the following Title V Permit authoriza

tions: O-1926, O-1927, O-1928, O-2158, and O-3826.



Accidental Release Prevention Program:

To prevent accidental releases, this facility is in compliance with the EPA Risk Management Program, and the OSHA Process Safety Management standard, and has fully implemented the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care Management System.+ The Caprolactam plants are equipped with many safety features designed to minimize oleum release potential.  The oleum drums are physically located in a diked containment area that flows into a spill pit.  In the event of a spill, the mineral oil system will provide a protective barrier that will reduce emissions.  The drums are protected against pressure and temperature fluctuations by a nitrogen blanketing system (for low pressures) and relief devices that vent through a scrubber (for high pressures). The drums and associated piping are routinely inspected for external and internal corrosion.  The drums are monitored via video camera and all of the drums have automated valves that can be shut from the control room. There are also water monitors surrounding the drums that would be used to knock down vapors from any spill.

+ As with other chemicals of concern, ammonia vessels are equipped with automatic shut-off and relief devices to handle fluctuations in temperature and pressure.  Warning alarms, regular equipment inspections and pressure monitoring in pipes and vessels provide layers of protection for employees and the community.

+ The formaldehyde storage tank is equipped with a spill pit to contain the contents of any accidental liquid releases.  A monitor nozzle is in place to control vapor releases from the tank.  Automatic shut-off devices, relief valves and safety alarms provide additional protection.

+ The acrylonitrile storage tank and its recirculation line are contained within a diked area to contain any liquid release.  The suction line at the bottom of the tank has an automated fire-safe shut-off valve.  There is a

n AR-AFFF foam system located above the diked area that can be activated remotely should a spill occur within the diked area.  The acrylonitrile truck unloading area sump drains to a spill pit that has an AR-AFFF foam addition system in case of a spill.  The foam would reduce vapor emissions.  There are also three LEL detectors located in the tank diked area and one located near the truck unloading area.

+ Chemical flammability is a great concern for BASF.  Many steps are taken to prevent accidental releases.  Thermal relief and automatic shut-off system are incorporated into process designs.  Systems are in place to quickly relocate or dispose of propylene, trimethylamine, and hydrogen in emergency situations.  Continuous monitoring of pipe and vessel pressure identifies potential leaks for further protection.  



Five Year Accident History:

This facility has had no accidental releases over the past five years which meet the reporting criteria.



Emergency Response Program:

Emergency response programs are in place for both internal preparation and coordination with the community. The Freeport Site plan is coordinated with the Brazoria County Local Emergency Planning Committee to ensure community safety. Drills are coordinated with the community and the community warning sirens are tested weekly.  In the event of an incident, information is transmitted over a local radio station. BASF participates in the Industrial CAER program (Community Awareness and Emergency Response), which operates a hotline for communication with the community.  In addition to the site plan, each operating unit has a block specific emergency plan.  These plans contain information specific to chemicals within the unit.  Incident commander training is conducted annually. Information on emergency health care is incorporated into the emergency plan. BASF also maintains a corporate-wide Emergency Response Team that is expertly trained in emergency mitigation techniques for transportation and

off-site incidents. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Facility processes are routinely changed to improve safety as a result of employee suggestions, process hazard analyses, incident investigations, etc.
